entry.title: Holiday Readiness â€“ Secure Your Backoffice Before Peak Season
entry.content:
As part of the SAP Holiday Season Readiness Program, weâ€™re helping you prepare for record-breaking traffic and sales. One critical step: protect your Backoffice and HAC from public exposure.

 

Why It Matters

Your Backoffice powers essential operations behind the scenes, non-customer-facing operations that supports crucial administrative and operational functions to ensure an e-commerce business runs smoothly, allowing businesses to scale.

Your Backoffice/HAC has administrative privileges in your e-commerce data and should not strictly be accessible publicly. It is vital to make sure that the environments are secure, to avoid a strong possibility of an attack leveraging them. If exposed to the internet, it becomes a high-value target for attackersâ€”especially during the holiday rush.

Risks of Exposure

  • ðŸ”“ Unauthorized Access - Attackers can discover and access internal systems without authentication barriers.
  • ðŸ¤– Brute Force & Credential Stuffing Attacks - Login portals are targeted with automated password-guessing tools.
  • ðŸ•µï¸â€ Sensitive Data Exposure - Internal dashboards or APIs may leak customer PII, business data, or system logs.
  • ðŸ’£ Malware & Ransomware Infection - Open endpoints can be used to deploy malicious payloads to internal systems.
  • â¬†ï¸ Privilege Escalation - If attackers get in, they may gain administrative privileges and full control of the backend.
  • ðŸ“‰ Reputational and Operational Impact - Downtime, data loss, and customer trust erosion can result from a breach.

How to Protect

  • Remove 0.0.0.0/0 (allow all) from your allow list.
  • Implement IP Filters and VPN for secure access.

ðŸ“š SAP Guidelines:

  • IP Filter Configuration
  • VPN Setup

Act now to secure your Backoffice before the holiday surge.

entry.title: Prevent Sensitive Data Exposure in URLs
entry.content:
High traffic means more transactionsâ€”and more risk. A common misconfiguration during integrations is sending PII data in the URL of a POST request instead of in the request body. This can lead to serious data leaks.

 

Why Itâ€™s Dangerous

URLs can be logged, cached, and exposed in browser history or analytics tools, making sensitive data vulnerable.

ðŸ”Learn more: OWASP Guidelines

How to Fix It

  • Configure the POST request in a secured way. Always send PII in the body of the POST request, never in the URL.

ðŸ“š SAP Guidelines:

  • SAP CX Commerce Cloud Security Guide

Secure your integrations now to protect customer trust during peak season.

entry.title: Eliminate Default Password Risks
entry.content:
Default passwords are an open invitation for attackers and should not be in use in your environments. All default passwords involved should be changed immediately to make sure that your environments are safe and secure. With holiday traffic surging, the stakes are higher than ever.

 

Whatâ€™s at Risk

  • ðŸ”“ Unauthorized Access - Attackers can log in easily using well-known default credentials.
  • ðŸ’¥ Website Defacement - Hackers may change content, inject malicious scripts, or vandalize the site.
  • ðŸ›  Privilege Escalation - Default credentials may allow full admin access.
  • ðŸ“‰ Reputational Damage - Compromises can erode user trust and damage your brand.

What You Should Do

  • Change all default passwords immediately.
  • Regularly review and update credentials.

ðŸ“š SAP Guidelines:

  • Change Backoffice Password
  • Update Built-in User Passwords

Need help? Open a support ticket today.

entry.title: Re: e-Doc Submission Error from SD Module Due to Missing...
entry.content:
1. Ensure Posting Before Sending
  • Confirm that the export document is posted in SAP before triggering the â€œSendâ€ action in the cockpit.
  • Posting ensures that the discharge date and other required fields are populated.
  1. Check for Missing Data
  • Use the error display feature in the cockpit:
    • Double-click the Logs/File column in the cockpit to open the details pane.
    • Review the application log, interface log, and last file for specific error messages.
  1. Correct and Resubmit
  • If the discharge date or other mandatory fields are missing:
    • Cancel the current eDocument.
    • Manually cancel the source document if needed.
    • Correct the data (e.g., populate the discharge date).
    • Resubmit the eDocument
  1. Customizing Settings
  • Ensure that the Document Compliance Framework is properly configured:
    • Maintain parameters in EDOGENCUST (e.g., NEW_SCREEN = X) to enable detailed error views.
    • Refer to SAP Note 3005076 for additional configuration guidance

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud Series â€“ Part 3: Customer-Managed Data Products
entry.content:
@MelCalucin : Please find the below answers:

  • In a typical medallion architecture, the layers serve different purposes:

    Bronze Data Layer: raw source data, ingested as-is. Silver Data Layer: cleansed and transformed data. Gold Data Layer: business-ready data enriched with semantics, associations, unions and joins.
    Depending on data quality from the source and business requirements, you may design 3 layers, 2 layers, or even just 1.

  • The exact approach depends on the use case. For example, a Sales Order CDS view already combines data from both Sales Header and Item views.

  • As a best practice, customers should leverage SAP-released CDS views first, extend them where needed, and only create custom CDS views when business requirements demand it. This is fully permissible under the clean core paradigm, as business requirements ultimately take priority.

Hope this helps, Jeet

entry.title: SAP MES - Add formula to work instruction?
entry.content:
Currently I have the following example system in place.

  • Part number 123 has an instruction to mill it to a thickness of 2in +/-.1in
  • Part Number 456 has an instruction to mill it to a thickness of 3in +/-.15in
  • Currently there are two work instructions one called Milling_123 where the instruction is fully written out as "Mill to 2in +/-.1in" and another instruction called Milling_456 where the instruction is written as "Mill to 3in +/-.15in"

Is it possible to add either a formula to a work instruction or some sort of parameterization so that we could have one instruction simply called "Milling" where it is written as something like

  • "Mill to _nominaldimension_ +/- _tolerance_" and those _xxx_ values are found by looking up values in the SQL database for each part number?
  • That way we only need one work instruction and we can make small clerical changes once while still keeping all of the important dimensions simply referenced from the database.
  • This sort of parameterization works for the formula function in data collection but I can't seem to find if it's possible to do it in work instructions.

entry.title: S4HPC Allergen information
entry.content:
Does sap S4HPC has functionality to handle the allergen material during put away in WM cloud. e.g. Business need to put away the material which has peanut and not to put away any other allergen material underneath it ( e.g. Soy)  Soy can go above the peanuts.

below functionality from on-premise https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_EXTENDED_WAREHOUSE_MANAGEMENT_INDUSTRY_ADD-ON_FOR_SAP_S4HANA/db74c75cb31f4cfa9ce951030222da7b/b94a1d5549224c6d9ec8b2c5058eff48.html 

You can use this process in warehouses dealing with allergen materials where the storage restrictions are considered during put-away. You can check and filter storage bins during put-away of allergen products for multiple allergen classes. For each possible put-away bin, the neighboring bins are checked during put-away.

entry.title: Re: How to Post Exchange Rate Differences to P&L Instead...
entry.content: @AlvaroFernandezMorales solution is to change the material's price control from Moving Average Price (V) to Standard Price (S) and then verify the account assignment for transaction keys PRD and KDM in the "Configure Automatic Account Determination" app (F1273).

entry.title: Re: How to Post Exchange Rate Differences to P&L Instead...
entry.content:
Hello @AlvaroFernandezMorales 

Thank you for your question.

The system behaviour you described is known. The reason behind that is, for inventory managed materials, all exchange rate differences between goods receipt and invoice receipt are posted into inventory valuation. This follows the moving average price principle in Public Cloud, where inventory reflects the true acquisition cost including currency fluctuation. Because of this, you cannot configure the system to post such differences directly to the P&L for stock materials.

The reason why you cannot change it via SSCUIs/Account determination is because in public cloud,

  • Account determination for Goods receipt/Invoice receipt and price differences is predefined and limited to configuration via SSCUIs.
  • However, foreign currency differences in purchase orders are automatically adjusted into the inventory if the material is stock-managed and not routed through the price difference or exchange rate different accounts.
  • The only time currency differences hit P&L account is when the procurement is for non-stock materials or service consumption postings but not for inventory.

There are a few options to serve as a workaround.

  • First one looks at non-stock procurement. If your requirement is to isolate FX differences in P&L then configure the material as consumption based. This ensures the entire purchase will hit P&L accounts which includes exchange rate variances.
  • Second, keep stock-manage procurement but report separately on exchange rate affects. You can do this through embedded analytics or custom CDS views.

Consider submitting a customer Influence Request for public cloud to allow routing FX differences to P&L.

Consult the below references for more details.

Inventory Balance Sheet Valuations (App ID: F3343)

Advanced Foreign Currency Valuation in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris
